briefdescription.para: Adds a tool to the toolbar.

parameterdescription.para: The tool to be added.

simplesect.para: After you have added tools to a toolbar, you must call Realize() in order to have the tools appear.
AddSeparator(), AddCheckTool(), AddRadioTool(), InsertTool(), DeleteTool(), Realize(), SetDropdownMenu()

memberdef.argsstring: (int toolId, const wxString &label, const wxBitmap &bitmap, const wxString &shortHelp=wxEmptyString, wxItemKind kind=wxITEM_NORMAL)
memberdef.name: AddTool

briefdescription.para: Adds a tool to the toolbar.

detaileddescription.para: This most commonly used version has fewer parameters than the full version below which specifies the more rarely used button features.

parameterdescription.para: An integer by which the tool may be identified in subsequent operations.
The string to be displayed with the tool.
The primary tool bitmap.
This string is used for the tools tooltip.

May be wxITEM_NORMAL for a normal button (default), wxITEM_CHECK for a checkable tool (such tool stays pressed after it had been toggled) or wxITEM_RADIO for a checkable tool which makes part of a radio group of tools each of which is automatically unchecked whenever another button in the group is checked. wxITEM_DROPDOWN specifies that a drop-down menu button will appear next to the tool button (only GTK+ and MSW). Call SetDropdownMenu() afterwards.

simplesect.para: After you have added tools to a toolbar, you must call Realize() in order to have the tools appear.
AddSeparator(), AddCheckTool(), AddRadioTool(), InsertTool(), DeleteTool(), Realize(), SetDropdownMenu()

memberdef.argsstring: (int toolId, const wxString &label, const wxBitmap &bitmap, const wxBitmap &bmpDisabled, wxItemKind kind=wxITEM_NORMAL, const wxString &shortHelpString=wxEmptyString, const wxString &longHelpString=wxEmptyString, wxObject *clientData=NULL)
memberdef.name: AddTool

briefdescription.para: Adds a tool to the toolbar.

parameterdescription.para: An integer by which the tool may be identified in subsequent operations.
The string to be displayed with the tool.
The primary tool bitmap.
The bitmap used when the tool is disabled. If it is equal to wxNullBitmap (default), the disabled bitmap is automatically generated by greying the normal one.

May be wxITEM_NORMAL for a normal button (default), wxITEM_CHECK for a checkable tool (such tool stays pressed after it had been toggled) or wxITEM_RADIO for a checkable tool which makes part of a radio group of tools each of which is automatically unchecked whenever another button in the group is checked. wxITEM_DROPDOWN specifies that a drop-down menu button will appear next to the tool button (only GTK+ and MSW). Call SetDropdownMenu() afterwards.
This string is used for the tools tooltip.
This string is shown in the statusbar (if any) of the parent frame when the mouse pointer is inside the tool.
An optional pointer to client data which can be retrieved later using GetToolClientData().

simplesect.para: After you have added tools to a toolbar, you must call Realize() in order to have the tools appear.
AddSeparator(), AddCheckTool(), AddRadioTool(), InsertTool(), DeleteTool(), Realize(), SetDropdownMenu()

memberdef.argsstring: (size_t pos, int toolId, const wxString &label, const wxBitmap &bitmap, const wxBitmap &bmpDisabled=wxNullBitmap, wxItemKind kind=wxITEM_NORMAL, const wxString &shortHelp=wxEmptyString, const wxString &longHelp=wxEmptyString, wxObject *clientData=NULL)
memberdef.name: InsertTool

briefdescription.para: Inserts the tool with the specified attributes into the toolbar at the given position.

detaileddescription.para: You must call Realize() for the change to take place.

simplesect.para: AddTool(), InsertControl(), InsertSeparator()
The newly inserted tool or NULL on failure. Notice that with the overload taking tool parameter the caller is responsible for deleting the tool in the latter case.

briefdescription.para: Inserts the tool with the specified attributes into the toolbar at the given position.

detaileddescription.para: You must call Realize() for the change to take place.

simplesect.para: AddTool(), InsertControl(), InsertSeparator()
The newly inserted tool or NULL on failure. Notice that with the overload taking tool parameter the caller is responsible for deleting the tool in the latter case.

briefdescription.para: Set the values to be used as margins for the toolbar.

parameterdescription.para: Left margin, right margin and inter-tool separation value.
Top margin, bottom margin and inter-tool separation value.

simplesect.para: This must be called before the tools are added if absolute positioning is to be used, and the default (zero-size) margins are to be overridden.

briefdescription.para: Set the margins for the toolbar.

parameterdescription.para: Margin size.

simplesect.para: This must be called before the tools are added if absolute positioning is to be used, and the default (zero-size) margins are to be overridden.
GetMargins(), wxSize

briefdescription.para: Default constructor.

memberdef.argsstring: (wxWindow *parent, wxWindowID id, const wxPoint &pos=wxDefaultPosition, const wxSize &size=wxDefaultSize, long style=wxTB_HORIZONTAL, const wxString &name=wxToolBarNameStr)
memberdef.name: wxToolBar

briefdescription.para: Constructs a toolbar.

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to a parent window.
Window identifier. If -1, will automatically create an identifier.
Window position. wxDefaultPosition indicates that wxWidgets should generate a default position for the window. If using the wxWindow class directly, supply an actual position.
Window size. wxDefaultSize indicates that wxWidgets should generate a default size for the window.
Window style. See wxToolBar initial description for details.
Window name.

simplesect.para: After a toolbar is created, you use AddTool() and perhaps AddSeparator(), and then you must call Realize() to construct and display the toolbar tools.

briefdescription.para: Toolbar destructor.

memberdef.argsstring: (int toolId, const wxString &label, const wxBitmap &bitmap1, const wxBitmap &bmpDisabled=wxNullBitmap, const wxString &shortHelp=wxEmptyString, const wxString &longHelp=wxEmptyString, wxObject *clientData=NULL)
memberdef.name: AddCheckTool

briefdescription.para: Adds a new check (or toggle) tool to the toolbar.

detaileddescription.para: The parameters are the same as in AddTool().

briefdescription.para: Adds any control to the toolbar, typically e.g.

detaileddescription.para: a wxComboBox.

parameterdescription.para: The control to be added.
Text to be displayed near the control.

simplesect.para: wxMSW: the label is only displayed if there is enough space available below the embedded control.
wxMac: labels are only displayed if wxWidgets is built with wxMAC_USE_NATIVE_TOOLBAR set to 1

memberdef.argsstring: (int toolId, const wxString &label, const wxBitmap &bitmap1, const wxBitmap &bmpDisabled=wxNullBitmap, const wxString &shortHelp=wxEmptyString, const wxString &longHelp=wxEmptyString, wxObject *clientData=NULL)
memberdef.name: AddRadioTool

briefdescription.para: Adds a new radio tool to the toolbar.

detaileddescription.para: Consecutive radio tools form a radio group such that exactly one button in the group is pressed at any moment, in other words whenever a button in the group is pressed the previously pressed button is automatically released. You should avoid having the radio groups of only one element as it would be impossible for the user to use such button.
By default, the first button in the radio group is initially pressed, the others are not.

briefdescription.para: Adds a separator for spacing groups of tools.

detaileddescription.para: Notice that the separator uses the look appropriate for the current platform so it can be a vertical line (MSW, some versions of GTK) or just an empty space or something else.

simplesect.para: AddTool(), SetToolSeparation(), AddStretchableSpace()

briefdescription.para: Adds a stretchable space to the toolbar.

detaileddescription.para: Any space not taken up by the fixed items (all items except for stretchable spaces) is distributed in equal measure between the stretchable spaces in the toolbar. The most common use for this method is to add a single stretchable space before the items which should be right-aligned in the toolbar, but more exotic possibilities are possible, e.g. a stretchable space may be added in the beginning and the end of the toolbar to centre all toolbar items.

simplesect.para: AddTool(), AddSeparator(), InsertStretchableSpace()

briefdescription.para: Deletes all the tools in the toolbar.
Removes the specified tool from the toolbar and deletes it.

detaileddescription.para: If you don't want to delete the tool, but just to remove it from the toolbar (to possibly add it back later), you may use RemoveTool() instead.

simplesect.para: It is unnecessary to call Realize() for the change to take place, it will happen immediately.
true if the tool was deleted, false otherwise.

briefdescription.para: This function behaves like DeleteTool() but it deletes the tool at the specified position and not the one with the given id.
Enables or disables the tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool to enable or disable, as passed to AddTool().
If true, enables the tool, otherwise disables it.

simplesect.para: Some implementations will change the visible state of the tool to indicate that it is disabled.
GetToolEnabled(), ToggleTool()

briefdescription.para: Returns a pointer to the tool identified by id or NULL if no corresponding tool is found.
Returns a pointer to the control identified by id or NULL if no corresponding control is found.
Finds a tool for the given mouse position.

parameterdescription.para: X position.
Y position.

simplesect.para: A pointer to a tool if a tool is found, or NULL otherwise.
Currently not implemented in wxGTK (always returns NULL there).

briefdescription.para: Returns the left/right and top/bottom margins, which are also used for inter-toolspacing.
Returns the size of bitmap that the toolbar expects to have.

detaileddescription.para: The default bitmap size is platform-dependent: for example, it is 16*15 for MSW and 24*24 for GTK. This size does not necessarily indicate the best size to use for the toolbars on the given platform, for this you should use wxArtProvider::GetNativeSizeHint(wxART_TOOLBAR) but in any case, as the bitmap size is deduced automatically from the size of the bitmaps associated with the tools added to the toolbar, it is usually unnecessary to call SetToolBitmapSize() explicitly.

simplesect.para: Note that this is the size of the bitmap you pass to AddTool(), and not the eventual size of the tool button.
SetToolBitmapSize(), GetToolSize()

briefdescription.para: Returns a pointer to the tool at ordinal position pos.

detaileddescription.para: Don't confuse this with FindToolForPosition().

briefdescription.para: Get any client data associated with the tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

simplesect.para: Client data, or NULL if there is none.

briefdescription.para: Called to determine whether a tool is enabled (responds to user input).

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

simplesect.para: true if the tool is enabled, false otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Returns the long help for the given tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

simplesect.para: SetToolLongHelp(), SetToolShortHelp()

briefdescription.para: Returns the value used for packing tools.
Returns the tool position in the toolbar, or wxNOT_FOUND if the tool is not found.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

briefdescription.para: Returns the default separator size.
Returns the short help for the given tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

simplesect.para: GetToolLongHelp(), SetToolShortHelp()

briefdescription.para: Returns the size of a whole button, which is usually larger than a tool bitmap because of added 3D effects.

simplesect.para: SetToolBitmapSize(), GetToolBitmapSize()

briefdescription.para: Gets the on/off state of a toggle tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

simplesect.para: true if the tool is toggled on, false otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of tools in the toolbar.
Inserts the control into the toolbar at the given position.

detaileddescription.para: You must call Realize() for the change to take place.

simplesect.para: AddControl(), InsertTool()

briefdescription.para: Inserts the separator into the toolbar at the given position.

detaileddescription.para: You must call Realize() for the change to take place.

simplesect.para: AddSeparator(), InsertTool()

briefdescription.para: Inserts a stretchable space at the given position.

detaileddescription.para: See AddStretchableSpace() for details about stretchable spaces.

simplesect.para: InsertTool(), InsertSeparator()

briefdescription.para: Called when the user clicks on a tool with the left mouse button.

detaileddescription.para: This is the old way of detecting tool clicks; although it will still work, you should use the EVT_MENU() or EVT_TOOL() macro instead.

parameterdescription.para: The identifier passed to AddTool().
true if the tool is a toggle and the toggle is down, otherwise is false.

simplesect.para: If the tool is a toggle and this function returns false, the toggle state (internal and visual) will not be changed. This provides a way of specifying that toggle operations are not permitted in some circumstances.
OnMouseEnter(), OnRightClick()

briefdescription.para: This is called when the mouse cursor moves into a tool or out of the toolbar.

detaileddescription.para: This is the old way of detecting mouse enter events; although it will still work, you should use the EVT_TOOL_ENTER() macro instead.

parameterdescription.para: Greater than -1 if the mouse cursor has moved into the tool, or -1 if the mouse cursor has moved. The programmer can override this to provide extra information about the tool, such as a short description on the status line.

simplesect.para: With some derived toolbar classes, if the mouse moves quickly out of the toolbar, wxWidgets may not be able to detect it. Therefore this function may not always be called when expected.

xrefdescription.para: This is the old way of detecting tool right clicks; although it will still work, you should use the EVT_TOOL_RCLICKED() macro instead.

detaileddescription.para: Called when the user clicks on a tool with the right mouse button. The programmer should override this function to detect right tool clicks.

parameterdescription.para: The identifier passed to AddTool().
The x position of the mouse cursor.
The y position of the mouse cursor.

simplesect.para: A typical use of this member might be to pop up a menu.
OnMouseEnter(), OnLeftClick()

briefdescription.para: This function should be called after you have added tools.
Removes the given tool from the toolbar but doesn't delete it.

detaileddescription.para: This allows to insert/add this tool back to this (or another) toolbar later.

simplesect.para: It is unnecessary to call Realize() for the change to take place, it will happen immediately.

briefdescription.para: Sets the bitmap resource identifier for specifying tool bitmaps as indices into a custom bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: This is a Windows CE-specific method not available in the other ports.
Availability:only available for the wxWinCE port. wxmsw_wince

briefdescription.para: Sets the dropdown menu for the tool given by its id.

detaileddescription.para: The tool itself will delete the menu when it's no longer needed. Only supported under GTK+ und MSW.
If you define a EVT_TOOL_DROPDOWN() handler in your program, you must call wxEvent::Skip() from it or the menu won't be displayed.

briefdescription.para: Sets the default size of each tool bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: The default bitmap size is 16 by 15 pixels.

parameterdescription.para: The size of the bitmaps in the toolbar.

simplesect.para: This should be called to tell the toolbar what the tool bitmap size is. Call it before you add tools.
GetToolBitmapSize(), GetToolSize()

briefdescription.para: Sets the client data associated with the tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

briefdescription.para: Sets the bitmap to be used by the tool with the given ID when the tool is in a disabled state.

detaileddescription.para: This can only be used on Button tools, not controls.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

simplesect.para: The native toolbar classes on the main platforms all synthesize the disabled bitmap from the normal bitmap, so this function will have no effect on those platforms.

briefdescription.para: Sets the long help for the given tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().
A string for the long help.

simplesect.para: You might use the long help for displaying the tool purpose on the status line.
GetToolLongHelp(), SetToolShortHelp(),

briefdescription.para: Sets the bitmap to be used by the tool with the given ID.

detaileddescription.para: This can only be used on Button tools, not controls.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().

briefdescription.para: Sets the value used for spacing tools.

detaileddescription.para: The default value is 1.

parameterdescription.para: The value for packing.

simplesect.para: The packing is used for spacing in the vertical direction if the toolbar is horizontal, and for spacing in the horizontal direction if the toolbar is vertical.

briefdescription.para: Sets the default separator size.

detaileddescription.para: The default value is 5.

parameterdescription.para: The separator size.

briefdescription.para: Sets the short help for the given tool.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().
The string for the short help.

simplesect.para: An application might use short help for identifying the tool purpose in a tooltip.
GetToolShortHelp(), SetToolLongHelp()

briefdescription.para: Toggles a tool on or off.

detaileddescription.para: This does not cause any event to get emitted.

parameterdescription.para: ID of the tool in question, as passed to AddTool().
If true, toggles the tool on, otherwise toggles it off.

simplesect.para: Only applies to a tool that has been specified as a toggle tool.

memberdef.argsstring: (int toolId, const wxString &label, const wxBitmap &bmpNormal, const wxBitmap &bmpDisabled=wxNullBitmap, wxItemKind kind=wxITEM_NORMAL, wxObject *clientData=NULL, const wxString &shortHelp=wxEmptyString, const wxString &longHelp=wxEmptyString)
memberdef.name: CreateTool

briefdescription.para: Factory function to create a new toolbar tool.
Factory function to create a new control toolbar tool.
A toolbar is a bar of buttons and/or other controls usually placed below the menu bar in a wxFrame.

detaileddescription.para: You may create a toolbar that is managed by a frame calling wxFrame::CreateToolBar(). Under Pocket PC, you should always use this function for creating the toolbar to be managed by the frame, so that wxWidgets can use a combined menubar and toolbar. Where you manage your own toolbars, create wxToolBar as usual.
There are several different types of tools you can add to a toolbar. These types are controlled by the wxItemKind enumeration.

Note that many methods in wxToolBar such as wxToolBar::AddTool return a wxToolBarToolBase* object. This should be regarded as an opaque handle representing the newly added toolbar item, providing access to its id and position within the toolbar. Changes to the item's state should be made through calls to wxToolBar methods, for example wxToolBar::EnableTool. Calls to wxToolBarToolBase methods (undocumented by purpose) will not change the visible state of the item within the tool bar.

This class supports the following styles:
wxTB_FLAT: Gives the toolbar a flat look (Windows and GTK only).
wxTB_DOCKABLE: Makes the toolbar floatable and dockable (GTK only).
wxTB_HORIZONTAL: Specifies horizontal layout (default).
wxTB_VERTICAL: Specifies vertical layout.
wxTB_TEXT: Shows the text in the toolbar buttons; by default only icons are shown.
wxTB_NOICONS: Specifies no icons in the toolbar buttons; by default they are shown.
wxTB_NODIVIDER: Specifies no divider (border) above the toolbar (Windows only)
wxTB_NOALIGN: Specifies no alignment with the parent window (Windows only, not very useful).
wxTB_HORZ_LAYOUT: Shows the text and the icons alongside, not vertically stacked (Windows and GTK 2 only). This style must be used with wxTB_TEXT.
wxTB_HORZ_TEXT: Combination of wxTB_HORZ_LAYOUT and wxTB_TEXT.
wxTB_NO_TOOLTIPS: Don't show the short help tooltips for the tools when the mouse hovers over them.
wxTB_BOTTOM: Align the toolbar at the bottom of parent window.
wxTB_RIGHT: Align the toolbar at the right side of parent window.
See also Window Styles. Note that the wxMSW native toolbar ignores wxTB_NOICONS style. Also, toggling the wxTB_TEXT works only if the style was initially on.

The following event handler macros redirect the events to member function handlers 'func' with prototypes like: voidhandlerFuncName(wxCommandEvent&event)Event macros for events emitted by this class:
EVT_TOOL(id, func): Process a wxEVT_COMMAND_TOOL_CLICKED event (a synonym for wxEVT_COMMAND_MENU_SELECTED). Pass the id of the tool.
EVT_MENU(id, func): The same as EVT_TOOL().
EVT_TOOL_RANGE(id1, id2, func): Process a wxEVT_COMMAND_TOOL_CLICKED event for a range of identifiers. Pass the ids of the tools.
EVT_MENU_RANGE(id1, id2, func): The same as EVT_TOOL_RANGE().
EVT_TOOL_RCLICKED(id, func): Process a wxEVT_COMMAND_TOOL_RCLICKED event. Pass the id of the tool. (Not available on wxOSX.)
EVT_TOOL_RCLICKED_RANGE(id1, id2, func): Process a wxEVT_COMMAND_TOOL_RCLICKED event for a range of ids. Pass the ids of the tools. (Not available on wxOSX.)
EVT_TOOL_ENTER(id, func): Process a wxEVT_COMMAND_TOOL_ENTER event. Pass the id of the toolbar itself. The value of wxCommandEvent::GetSelection() is the tool id, or -1 if the mouse cursor has moved off a tool. (Not available on wxOSX.)
EVT_TOOL_DROPDOWN(id, func): Process a wxEVT_COMMAND_TOOL_DROPDOWN_CLICKED event. If unhandled, displays the default dropdown menu set using wxToolBar::SetDropdownMenu().
The toolbar class emits menu commands in the same way that a frame menubar does, so you can use one EVT_MENU() macro for both a menu item and a toolbar button. The event handler functions take a wxCommandEvent argument. For most event macros, the identifier of the tool is passed, but for EVT_TOOL_ENTER() the toolbar window identifier is passed and the tool identifier is retrieved from the wxCommandEvent. This is because the identifier may be wxID_ANY when the mouse moves off a tool, and wxID_ANY is not allowed as an identifier in the event system.
Library:wxCore
Category:Miscellaneous Windows
